Disclaimer: I understand there are many reasons why people choose not to participate in various holidays and respect that. This is not intended to convince people who don't celebrate Valentine's Day for whatever reason, but to present an idea of it that is inclusive IF people want to participate but feel that they are not "allowed" to. SO, VALENTINE'S DAY. I HEAR A LOT OF PEOPLE DON'T ENJOY IT. That's cool. I mean, I don't enjoy all holidays. I don't celebrate the same holidays as a lot of people, either! And I totally get that most holidays have really problematic aspects to them. But I love Valentine's Day. And here is why! I was pretty lucky as a kid in a lot of ways. One of these ways is that for the most part my family was a good family, and they loved me, and a lot of the things my parents did and taught me when I was small have affected how I see things now as an adult. I guess Valentine's Day is one of those things. When I was a kid, Valentine's Day was never about just romantic love or sexual love, at all! For as long as I can remember, my dad would hide little notes and chocolates around the house for me and my mother to find. In the morning we all opened cards from everyone, my parents and my grandparents both. My grandfather always sent us chocolate. I realize that I was and am really privileged to be a part of a family who is able to do that kind of thing, and I think the main idea that I took away from it was: this day is about love. It's not about an exclusive kind of love that huge swathes of people are left out of because they don't somehow qualify as being allowed to celebrate. It isn't about the people who are dating or married one person. It's about everyone. It's about me, and you, and the people who care about and support and love all of us. I realize I am somewhat... unusually keen on Valentine's Day (possibly this is an understatement)! I don't ever expect everyone else or even most other people to be as excited about it as I am, or excited about it in the same ways I am! That would be silly. But I think we get sold this idea of the holiday that is extremely narrow and leaves many, many people feeling left out and upset, and I think that there are ways to think about it which solve that problem. So yeah, we all know the most common Valentine's Day narrative: it is for young heterosexual couples who are in love and having sex! To ply each other with overpriced gifts! Buy your ladyfriend a diamond and she'll put out! Etc, etc. I absolutely think that the gender-essentialist and heterosexist undertones we're commonly presented with are harmful (and stupid). And I absolutely understand the resentment a lot of people feel towards a lot of the commercialism of the holiday, for sure. But! I don't quite understand rejecting the entire day and dwelling in bitterness because of it! Many, many potentially enjoyable things are commercialized in problematic ways. There are still ways to enjoy them and buying into the packaged and marketed and sold idea of what Valentine's Day SHOULD look like is only one of the near-infinite ways to participate. It doesn't have to be about romance or your ~one twuu heterosexual lurrv partner~! In fact, I reject that idea. If that idea was sitting next to me in a James Bond car, I would hit the seat eject button so hard that that idea would be launched into space. NO LIE. Heterosexual romantic love does not have a monopoly on love. There are infinite kinds of love and caring and support and relationships humans can and do have with one another. They are ALL valuable and they are ALL worth celebrating. For me it was about my family, and then later about my friends - the people in my life who I love and care about and who love and care about me. For me, this day is about remembering and appreciating the people in my life and trying to do something to show them that they are appreciated. Does that mean it can't be about romance or sex or couples? Hell no! They can participate too! I am totally making my girlfriend a card covered in love hearts and glitter and sending her some heart-shaped cookies. I'm also making those things for a lot of my friends who I am NOT dating and who I have no interest in dating! Because I love them, too. In different ways. But they are all just as important to me. When I was working at Bivouac I made cards every year for all my co-workers. When I was a kid I used to draw them for my cats and then tape the cards to their litter boxes! Cats don't appreciate this, or know what Valentine's Day is, because they are cats. But your friends and family and co-workers and acquaintances and anyone who you care about who doesn't fit into those categories... they all do! Everyone likes to be appreciated, in whatever way you choose to show them you appreciate them. One of the nicest things about spreading the Valentine's Day love outside the expected boundaries of "romantic partner" is that people don't expect it. Yeah, most of our media and society does perpetuate the idea that if you are not in a monogamous heterosexual romantic partnership of some kind you are a failure. So you know what I say? Fuck that! You're not a failure. And the other part to this post is: You're not "single". Just because you don't have ~a date~ does not mean you are alone. Think about all the people in your life. You have people you love and care about and people who love and care about you! Whether they are your parent(s), or aunts or uncles, or grandparent(s), or friends, you have people in your life. If you are reading this, chances are *I* care about and love you, for one! :D And even though I only managed to send out about 20 cards this year, and there's more than 20 people who I want to reach out to and appreciate, I want everyone to know that I, or someone else in your life, loves you. Fuck anyone who tells you that they don't count because they're not your boyfriend or girlfriend. Fuck anyone who says that you shouldn't be able to participate in this holiday because you don't have the RIGHT kind of love. All love is the right kind of love. This holiday is for you. Time for me to get really really frustrated about all the Christmas stuff up everywhere And apparently time for almost everyone who celebrates it to act like my objecting to this is just due to the fact that I want to be ~treated special~ or because I want to ruin everyone else's fun. YES, YOU CAUGHT ME! I JUST HATE HOLIDAYS. OBVIOUSLY. Hoo-fucking-ray. I think what people don't realize is how lonely it can be? I mean... it's hard because I DO like fun, and lights and presents and food and parties and pine trees and candles and being with family and friends, I like all those things, but if I want to participate in them I have to either discard my own cultural identity or ...make other people acknowledge my holidays, which people always get all eye-roll-y about. Even though, you know, we are all expected to acknowledge Christian holidays. It's just pretty fucking sad-making, I guess. Especially when it is SO easy to say "holiday" instead of "Christmas". There's lots of things I would have participated in when I was younger because it's easier to just try to push the not-belonging to the back of your mind and leave your culture at the door sometimes, but I can't do it any more. I was just thinking, and... the interesting thing about death is that you don't KNOW you are going to die until you do. You can be intellectually aware of the likelihood of its occurring being damn near 100% eventually, or even aware of its imminent occurrence being VERY likely, perhaps if one has some manner of chronic disease, in which case one is very unpleasantly alive, but still alive. Until one is dead. At which point one does not exist anymore. Sure, previous evidence points to YOU WILL DIE but you cannot know that FOR SURE. It is extremely probable. But improbable things happen all the time; being alive at all is extremely improbable. As many ways as there are of being alive there are infinitely more ways of being dead. I will not be dead until I am dead at which point I WILL BE DEAD so I will not be able to know that I am dead. So, from the perspective of a human experiencing the world from inside our minds, which is the vantage point from which we all experience the world, we are never dead. DO YOU SEE WHAT I AM SAYING? One never experiences being dead, so being dead is literally something that happens to other people. Death does not happen to us individually because as soon as it has occurred we are not us anymore. So, from the inside, are we all immortal? I like to think so. This entry was originally posted at http://pob.dreamwidth.org/251485.html. Please comment there using OpenID.

The meeting with my tutor went bizarrely well. HOWEVER, this post is not about that. This post is about being bewildered about how much racism I keep finding in Jewish stuff lately So like right I am Jewish and I think that's pretty rad and I like learning about the culture and history of my ~people~ and stuff, right. As you do! I was reading a lot of stuff about various old Jewish quarters and areas in London, and I came across a guide to visiting Important Old Jew Places. Soooo I was reading the info, and it all sounded interesting until I got to this part: "The several hundred Jews who remain here, who still call the East End home, now live among a Muslim population - a latter day immigration of Bengalis, Pakistanis, and assorted Arabs. Some synagogues have been converted into mosques; many of those, like the one at the corner of Brick Lane and Fournier Street, preach a fundamentalist Islam that has no use for outsiders and even less use for Jews." I beg your fucking pardon???? WHAT THE SHIT IS THIS SHIT, YOU GUYS. I DON'T EVEN KNOW WHERE TO BEGIN. It's not like the Jews got kicked out of the East End - they lived there cos it's a place where poor immigrants traditionally are ABLE to live! Many of them moved to places that were not holes! Then other immigrant groups moved in! THIS IS OFTEN HOW IT WORKS! Also no one just... appeared in the night, STEALTHILY, and STOLE those synagogues, hiring hundreds of SECRET NIGHT CONSTRUCTION WORKERS to turn them into mosques while NO ONE WAS LOOKING!!! It's not like the East End has been the victim of like secret STEALTH MUSLIM ACTION or something oh my god!!! And yes, no Jewish groups are ever fundamentalist or exclusive. (YOU SEE THIS IS ACTUALLY A JOKE BECAUSE MANY OF THEM ARE) So, whatever. I was disappointed that my keenness in learning stuff about Jews in London was interrupted by SURPRISE RACISM but I moved on. Fast forward to about a week later: I was looking at my book shelf (read: haphazard book stack) for something to read on the tube. I did not feel like heavy-handed Word Of God crap that morning, so I grabbed an anthology of stories and legends of the Russian Jews in lieu of Les Mis. In my experience, Jewish folktales and so on are clever and humorous and passed down for ages and ages! I thought I was going to be safe :( BUT NO TURNS OUT the book I selected was EVEN WORSE at doing the horrible heavy-handed 19th century WORD OF GOD voiceover narration - and not even in a humorous or interesting or thought-provoking way like Mr Hugo generally is. I got extremely wary when, in the introduction, the guy who compiled the stories said that Jewish tales "in point of inventiveness can vie with the Arabian NIghts' Entertainments, and in ideality and moral elevation far surpass them", but I thought... maybe it was just a passing dickhead remark by some bitter contemporary compiler-of-stories and did not signal anything about the contents of the actual narratives. OH HOW WRONG I WAS. The very first sentence in the very first story goes thus: "Tangier is held by the Moors to be the most beautiful city of the European hemisphere, and their patriotic conceit is explained by the circumstance that very few of Moslem birth go to the trouble of crossing the Strait to look even at the great fortress of Gibraltar." ...I'll just let that sink in a moment. Right. Okay. So at this point I am like "fml" but I kept reading that one for a couple of pages just in case. The narrator goes on and on about how fucking great Gibraltar is for a while, and then circles back to Tangier, stating that "During nine months of the year the climate along the Moorish coast facing Spain is delightful. Yet, notwithstanding the benignity of the skies and the fertility of the soil, man vegetates here in squalor, poverty, and ignorance, the historic trinity of Oriental barbarism." A few lines later it refers to the "superstition, fanaticism, and indolence" which are "common plagues of unenlightened Islam". I HATE EVERYTHING. By that point I had progressed rapidly through shock, disbelief, anger, and offense, and landed squarely in "oh my god I can't believe I am holding this book in public". Really most of my feelings, though, can be summarized as let down. How hard is it to find interesting historic and cultural artifacts or information about the group of people whose culture I share without encountering offensive bullshit like this? Can I please get some Jewpride WITHOUT the side order of horrible anti-Islam rhetoric? FOR FUCK'S SAKE. I did try to read some of the other stories which DIDN'T have stuff about Islam in them but they were just trite boring morality tales about people building giant fire-breathing iron golems to kill other people. Which might have been somewhat interesting (we all know how much I like golems and over the top apocalyptic ~REVENGE!!!~ nonsense) but it was just bitter and uninteresting. And it takes a lot to make me disinterested in golems. TRULY. I am so disappointed, you guys. Why weren't these humorous folktales about wise Rabbis telling townsfolk to invite goats into their houses or about poor men going to banquets and pouring soup into their boots??? WHERE ARE THE AMAZING JEWISH FOLKTALES OF MY YOUTH :( :( :( So fuck this, the next book about anything remotely Jew-related I read will be this one. It probably doesn't have golems, but you cannot win them all.
